headline: Thulium | video
text: This week's element is thulium, a lanthanide that has the symbol, Tm, and the atomic number, 69. It is very rare, being only slightly more common on Earth than promethium. Like the other lanthanides, thulium is never found in its pure form in nature. Of all the lanthanides, thulium is the most forgotten (by me), since I always forget I've ever heard of this one except when I see its symbol, Tm, which my mind always transliterates as "Tim".  So let me tell you more about this lanthanide known as thulium and with the nickname "Tim". As you can see in the above image, pure thulium metal is quite lovely; being lustrous silver. It is soft, malleable, and ductile. One can also think of "Tim", er, thulium as having several sorts of personality types, depending upon ambient temperatures; it is ferromagnetic* below 32 K, antiferromagnetic** between 32 and 56 K and paramagnetic*** above 56 K. [*ferromagnetism: is a strong form of magnetism where neighbouring electron spins are opposition. **antiferromagnetism: is strong magnetism shown by alignment of neighbouring electron spins. Thanks, pseudosp1n, for your help. ***paramagnetism: weak magnetism that pops up only in the presence of an externally applied magnetic field.] Thulium is rare and expensive, so it doesn't have many commercial uses since almost no one (including chemists!) can afford it. Further, it has no role in biology, so biologists aren't much interested in it, either. That said, thulium does have its uses: thulium isotopes created in nuclear reactors are used as a portable x-ray source for dental and medical use. It also is used as a dopant in YAG (Remember YAG? It's short for Yttrium Aluminium Garnet, which has the chemical formula Y3Al5O12). YAG is used in lasers that emit wavelengths in a very narrow operating range, so they are safe for laser surgery. (think: eyes. I have briefly mentioned the wonders of YAG before.) But how did "Tim", er, thulium get its weird name? As usual, we have the Swedes to thank for that. Thulium was originally discovered by Swedish chemist Per Teodor Cleve, who originally isolated it in its oxide form. After Cleve became convinced this green powder was another element, he named it for Thule, Scandinavia, which was then Latinised to be consistent with most of the other elements' names.  Later, British expat, Charles James, discovered bromate fractional crystallization to purify thulium in relatively large quantities ("large" in this case is another way to say "visible with the naked eye") -- a process that required 15,000 "operations" to establish that the resulting material was homogeneous. (The dedication this demanded makes me wonder whether James was trying avoid spending evenings and weekends in the local pubs.)
